abstract: NiNE-year-old Dolores B remains playful and lively despite a neurological disease that has left her unable to control her limbs or walk without support. She laughs off her embarrassment when an unintentional movement brings the stack of blocks a brother has built tumbling down.    But her mother cries when she speaks of Dolores and the hardship her brothers, Jorge, 7, and Carlos, 14, have endured since their sister's degenerative disease was diagnosed a year ago.

lead_paragraph: In six months of homelessness, the low point for Alicia Payton came last May, when her father died. ''I am living in a shelter,'' she says she thought. ''My dad is gone. I have to get an apartment. I have to finish school. What's going to happen next? If I have to die trying, I am going to get my kids out of this.'' Safeguarding the children has always been her top priority.

abstract: The birth of a grandchild is normally a joyous occasion filled with hope, good will and warmth of family and friends.  But for Norma L, afflicted with arthritic pain, a heart condition, and mounting debts, the birth not long ago of Jonathan - the second child of her only son - was an occasion that also brought with it sadness and tears.   ''I'm so happy but at the same time I'm so worried and depressed,'' Mrs. L said. ''I have so much to live for but I'm afraid that soon I won't even be able to hold the baby or even afford crib sheets.'

abstract: Helping the neediest New Yorkers often means recognizing the peril of the city's neediest neighborhoods. That was what the Children's Aid Society, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, did when it took a hard look at a block of 118th Street in Harlem, where it helped Ella M. and her four children, including Adzil, 1, left, and Adzelle, 3, find shelter and a sense of community. ''People would say, 'One block? How can you invest so many resources in one block?' '' said Philip Coltoff, who heads the Children's Aid Society. ''But one block in New York City could have a thousand people living in it. That's as many people as in a village. And some problems in New York City can only be solved block by block.''      Article, page 61.
lead_paragraph: Helping the neediest New Yorkers often means recognizing the peril of the city's neediest neighborhoods. That was what the Children's Aid Society, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, did when it took a hard look at a block of 118th Street in Harlem, where it helped Ella M. and her four children, including Adzil, 1, left, and Adzelle, 3, find shelter and a sense of community. ''People would say, 'One block? How can you invest so many resources in one block?' '' said Philip Coltoff, who heads the Children's Aid Society. ''But one block in New York City could have a thousand people living in it. That's as many people as in a village. And some problems in New York City can only be solved block by block.''

abstract: Revisiting three cases from the 2005-6 campaign shows how timely assistance, and the continuing support of the beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, have turned lives around.
snippet: Revisiting three cases from the 2005-6 campaign shows how timely assistance, and the continuing support of the beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, have turned lives around.
lead_paragraph: Every day, Neediest Cases articles offer glimpses into the lives of New York’s poor. Often, the subjects have recently survived a crisis  or are still in one  and their futures seem uncertain at best. Revisiting three cases from the 2005-6 campaign shows how timely assistance, and the continuing support of the seven agencies that are the beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, have turned lives around.

lead_paragraph: In 1994, when Jennie Wright first saw her husband, Walter, fall asleep at the kitchen table while paying the family's bills, she assumed he was simply tired.

headline.main: Support Group Helps Man Live With His Limitations
headline.print_headline: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Support Group Helps Man Live With His Limitations

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

abstract: By Robert E. Marks   Irving C, a 45-year-old double amputee confined to a wheelchair, spent last Christmas in the front seat of an old car parked in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.   He has been paralysed below the waist since a shooting incident in 1965, when he was 27. A few years later, when he developed circulatory problems, his legs had to be amputated.   He said his medical condition left him too embarrassed to seek help at a social services center. For the past six years, he lived alone in the front seat of a four-door 1971 Cadillac Sedan de Ville, using the back seat to store his wheelchair and some clothing.
lead_paragraph: By Robert E. Marks

abstract: Charlen Evans, who has been hearing-impaired her whole life, got a cochlear implant in 2012. She has since returned to college in hopes of someday working with deaf students.
snippet: Charlen Evans, who has been hearing-impaired her whole life, got a cochlear implant in 2012. She has since returned to college in hopes of someday working with deaf students.
lead_paragraph: Strangers approach Charlen Evans, on street corners and city buses, when they notice her cochlear implant. They greet her by placing a finger just below their ear, gliding it in an arc across the cheek and stopping just shy of the mouth.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund invests contributions of $100,000 or more from trusts and estates in an endowment. The income, recently more than $1 million a year, goes to the next year’s campaign. These are the trusts and estates that donated to the fund during this year’s campaign.

abstract: Carlos Guevara used to sit hunched over a sewing machine 10 hours a day, six days a week. He lost his job in October 2001, and now longs for hard work. He and his wife live in Queens and have three children. They are described as the working poor -- they have income, but not enough.    Article, Page 46.

abstract: Just teenagers when their single mother died young, Andre Steinberg and Jamal Perry have kept pushing forward, with a little help from Catholic Charities.
snippet: Just teenagers when their single mother died young, Andre Steinberg and Jamal Perry have kept pushing forward, with a little help from Catholic Charities.
lead_paragraph: The brothers enjoy their endless little debates. They could be over something of importance, but then again, maybe not. Just the other week, they got at it over how many Batman movies there had been. Why, obviously there had been four, according to Andre Steinberg. What is wrong with you, there were seven, Jamal Perry insisted.

abstract: Staff Sgt. Sandra Rolon spent more than a year in Kuwait serving her country, now she is unable to refinance her home or make her mortgage payments.
snippet: Staff Sgt. Sandra Rolon spent more than a year in Kuwait serving her country, now she is unable to refinance her home or make her mortgage payments.
lead_paragraph: Staff Sgt. Sandra Rolon spent more than a year in Kuwait, managing food service operations at a military base as part of the 408th Personnel Service Battalion in the U.S. Army Reserve. She thought of her time there in 2004 as a way both to serve her country and to pursue a more personal goal: buying a home.

abstract: With one day left in its 83d campaign, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund still has a chance to match last year's total of $4.59 million. It would have to collect another $250,000, a task that is formidable but not impossible.   Contributions dated no later than March 1 and received by March 8 will be included in this year's appeal. The total today -- $4,346,550.81 -- is the lowest since 1989, when the fund raised $4,039,728.75. The number of donors this year -- 11,820 as of last Friday -- is also unusually low. Last year, 13,500 individuals and foundations sent money to the fund. In 1993, almost 14,000 did so.
lead_paragraph: With one day left in its 83d campaign, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund still has a chance to match last year's total of $4.59 million. It would have to collect another $250,000, a task that is formidable but not impossible.
